dt: {bc}a rigid or semirigid container typically of glass or plastic having a comparatively narrow neck or mouth and usually no handle
{bc}a usually bottle-shaped container made of skin for storing a liquid

dt.t: slipped deeper and deeper into the {wi}bottle{/wi}

dt: {bc}liquid food (such as milk) used in place of mother's milk

et: Middle English {it}botel{/it}, from Old French {it}botele{/it}, from Medieval Latin {it}butticula{/it}, diminutive of Late Latin {it}buttis{/it} cask
shortdef: a rigid or semirigid container typically of glass or plastic having a comparatively narrow neck or mouth and usually no handle
a usually bottle-shaped container made of skin for storing a liquid
the quantity held by a bottle

dt: {bc}a person whose hair has been bleached blond

shortdef: a person whose hair has been bleached blond

dt: {bc}a club serving patrons previously purchased or reserved alcoholic drinks after normal legal closing hours

dt: {bc}an inexpensively produced episode of a television series that is typically confined to one setting

dt.t: After weeks spent in the field, {it}The Last Ship{/it} got back to basics tonight by delivering a very satisfying {wi}bottle episode{/wi} that kept everyone situated on the ship.

The six-part series is made up of mostly {ldquo}{wi}bottle episodes{/wi},{rdquo} meaning the action takes place in one location. While that situation is a facility of a small budget, it has turned out to be a bit of a creative windfall.

et: The notion that the phrase grew out of the television series {it}Star Trek{/it} is contravened by Robert H. Justman, a coproducer of the original {it}Star Trek.{/it} In discussing the alternation of "planet shows" with "ship shows" on the series, Justman mentions that "most other series called them [ship shows] 'bottle shows,' but regardless of what they were called, their purpose was the same: to save money by 'bottling up' the action … Our ship shows took place entirely on board the {it}Enterprise{/it} and cost much less to produce" (Herbert F. Solow and Robert H. Justman, {it}Inside Star Trek: the Real Story,{/it} Pocket Books, 1996, p. 253). In {it}The Outer Limits: The Official Companion{/it} (New York: Ace Science Fiction Books, 1986) the book's authors David J. Schow and Jeffrey Frentzen attribute the coinage of {it}bottle show{/it} to Leslie Stevens, producer of the series {it}The Outer Limits{/it} (1963-65): "No one believed Leslie Stevens when he proposed to complete an {it}Outer Limits{/it} episode in four days … until he went ahead and did it. The skeleton of 'Controlled Experiment' [broadcast 13 January 1964] was typed up by Stevens on a New York to LA flight, and the show took four and a half shooting days to complete. At $100,000, it was the cheapest {it}Outer Limits{/it} ever. Stevens dubbed this last-minute lifesaving technique the 'bottle show'—as in pulling an episode right out of a bottle like a genie. 'When they know you can do it, and do it fast, you become the fire department, to bail the show out of trouble,' said Stevens" (p. 86). (Schow and Frentzen interviewed Leslie Stevens expressly for the book.)
shortdef: an inexpensively produced episode of a television series that is typically confined to one setting

dt: {bc}a common cultivated gourd ({it}Lagenaria siceraria{/it}) having a variably shaped fruit with a hard shell that is sometimes used as a container

shortdef: a common cultivated gourd (Lagenaria siceraria) having a variably shaped fruit with a hard shell that is sometimes used as a container

dt: {bc}a {d_link|firework|firework} typically consisting of a cylindrical case that is partly filled with combustible material and fastened to a guiding stick which may be placed in a bottle to control the direction of the rocket's launch

dt: {bc}a large container that people put empty bottles in so that the glass or plastic the bottles are made from can be used again

shortdef: a large container that people put empty bottles in so that the glass or plastic the bottles are made from can be used again
